Cell. 1996; 86: 353-364Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (5991) Google Scholar, 2Pepper M.S. Arterioscler. Thromb. Vasc. Biol. 1997; 17: 605-619Crossref PubMed Scopus (261) Google Scholar, 3Carmeliet P. Jain R.K. Nature. 2000; 407: 249-258Crossref PubMed Scopus (7284) Google Scholar). Angiogenesis requires endothelial cells (EC) 1The abbreviations used are: EC, endothelial cells; MT1-MMP, membrane type 1-matrix metalloproteinase; SS, shear stress; MMPS, matrix metalloproteinases; EMSA, electrophoretic mobility shift assay; PBS, phosphate-buffered saline; GAPDH, glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase. 1The abbreviations used are: EC, endothelial cells; MT1-MMP, membrane type 1-matrix metalloproteinase; SS, shear stress; MMPS, matrix metalloproteinases; EMSA, electrophoretic mobility shift assay; PBS, phosphate-buffered saline; GAPDH, glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase.to coordinate multiple functions including reduction of intercellular adhesion, degradation of subendothelial matrix, migration, proliferation, and formation of new capillary tubes (4Risau W. Nature. 1997; 386: 671-674Crossref PubMed Scopus (4755) Google Scholar). The matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) are a family of structurally related zinc endopeptidases capable of proteolysis of numerous components of the extracellular matrix (5Woessner J.F. Ann. N. Y. Acad. Sci. 1994; 732: 11-21Crossref PubMed Scopus (435) Google Scholar). Production and activation of MMPs correlate strongly with migration and invasion in endothelium (6Birkedal-Hansen H. Curr. Opin. Cell Biol. 1995; 7: 728-735Crossref PubMed Scopus (973) Google Scholar, 7Mignatti P. Rifkin D.B. Curr. Top. Microbiol. Immunol. 1996; 213: 33-50Crossref PubMed Scopus (33) Google Scholar). Membrane type-1 matrix metalloproteinase (MT1-MMP, MMP-14), one of the members of the family of matrix-bound MMPs by a C-terminal transmembrane domain, is identified as a physiological activator of pro-MMP-2 on the cell surface as well as a functional enzyme that degrades a number of extracellular matrix components (8Sato H. Takino T. Okada Y. Cao J. Shinagawa A. Yamamoto E. Seiki M. Nature. 1994; 370: 61-65Crossref PubMed Scopus (2361) Google Scholar, 9Strongin A.Y. Collier I. Bannikov G. Marmer B.L. Grant G.A. Goldberg G.I. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 5331-5338Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1432) Google Scholar). It is not surprising that MT1-MMP has been shown to be a key regulator of angiogenesis (10Hiraoka N. Allen E. Apel I.J. Gyetko M.R. Weiss S.J. Cell. 1998; 95: 365-377Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (636) Google Scholar,11Sato H. Okada Y. Seiki M. Thromb. Haemostasis. 1997; 78: 497-500Crossref PubMed Scopus (103) Google Scholar). MT1-MMP mRNA and protein levels are expressed at low levels in most noninvasive cells but are up-regulated during EC migration and matrix remodeling, and this up-regulation correlates with MMP-2 activation (11Sato H. Okada Y. Seiki M. Thromb. Haemostasis. 1997; 78: 497-500Crossref PubMed Scopus (103) Google Scholar). The up-regulation of MT1-MMP mRNA and protein occurs in microvascular EC cultured in a three-dimensional collagen type-I matrix as a consequence of increased production and promoter binding of the transcription factor early growth response (Egr-1) (12Haas T.L. Davis S.J. Madri J.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 3604-3610Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (322) Google Scholar, 13Haas T.L. Stitelman D. Davis S.J. Apte S.S. Madri J.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 22679-22685Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (173) Google Scholar). Egr-1 is a key regulator of MT1-MMP activation and is involved in the differentiation to a migratory and invasive endothelial phenotype (13Haas T.L. Stitelman D. Davis S.J. Apte S.S. Madri J.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 22679-22685Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (173) Google Scholar). However, the regulation of MT1-MMP expression and the mechanism of its activation induced by environmental forces are not well understood. We demonstrated previously (14Yamaguchi S. Yamaguchi M. Yatsuyanagi E. Yun S.S. Nakajima N. Madri J.A. Sumpio B. Lab. Invest. 2002; 82: 949-956Crossref PubMed Scopus (61) Google Scholar) that cyclic strain induced up-regulation of MT1-MMP mRNA and protein in microvascular EC. We also demonstrated that a GC-rich sequence between −288 and −275 in the promoter contains overlapping consensus binding sites for Sp1 and Egr-1, and increasing levels of Egr-1 displace the basal transcription factor Sp1 from the MT1-MMP promoter, resulting in a significantly greater rate of transcription (13Haas T.L. Stitelman D. Davis S.J. Apte S.S. Madri J.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 22679-22685Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (173) Google Scholar). Other studies have shown that fluid shear stress increases Egr-1 expression but decreases MT1-MMP mRNA and protein expression in vascular smooth muscle cells (15Palumbo R. Gaetano C. Melillo G. Toschi E. Remuzzi A. Capogrossi M.C. Circulation. 2000; 102: 225-230Crossref PubMed Scopus (81) Google Scholar). In this study, we investigate the regulation of MT1-MMP expression in microvessel EC by shear stress and the roles of the transcription factors Egr-1 and Sp1 in this process. Rat microvascular EC were harvested from the epididymal fat pads of Sprague-Dawley rats and cultured as described previously (16Madri J.A. Williams S.K. J. Cell Biol. 1983; 97: 153-165Crossref PubMed Scopus (444) Google Scholar). Twelve rats were used per preparation, and experiments were performed on two separate isolations of cells. Briefly, cells were grown on gelatin-coated tissue culture plates (1.5% gelatin in phosphate-buffered saline) and maintained in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium (Invitrogen) containing 25% sterile-filtered conditioned bovine aortic EC medium and 10% fetal bovine serum. For all experiments, EC were cultured in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium (Invitrogen) containing 10% heat-inactivated fetal calf serum (HyClone Laboratories, Logan, UT) and antibiotics (penicillin 100 units/ml, streptomycin 100 μg/ml, and amphotericin B 250 ng/ml (Invitrogen)) in a humidified atmosphere of 5% CO2 on type I collagen-coated 35-mm 6-well culture dishes at 37 °C. Serum-containing medium was replaced by serum-free medium 24 h prior to each experiment. Cells were synchronized by serum-starving for 24 h. Shear stress was applied to confluent cultures with an orbital shaker (Lab-Line, Melrose Park, IL) (17Ley K. Lundgren E. Berger E. Arfors K.E. Blood. 1989; 73: 1324-1330Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 18Pearce M.J. McIntyre T.M. Prescott S.M. Zimmerman G.A. Whatley R.E. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1996; 218: 500-504Crossref PubMed Scopus (107) Google Scholar, 19Kraiss L.W. Weyrich A.S. Alto N.M. Dixon D.A. Ennis T.M. Modur V. McIntyre T.M. Prescott S.M. Zimmerman G.A. Am. J. Physiol. 2000; 278: H1537-H1544PubMed Google Scholar). Although this technique does not result in uniform application of laminar shear stress across the entire monolayer, the majority of the cells are exposed to near-maximal shear stress (τmax), which can be calculated as shown in Equation1, τmax=a√ρη¯(2πf)3Equation 1 where a is the radius of orbital rotation (1.4 cm); ρ is the density of the culture medium (1.0 g/ml); η is the viscosity of the medium (0.0075 poise measured by viscometer); andf is the frequency of rotation (rotations/s). A shaking frequency of 270 rpm results in a shear stress of 14 dynes/cm2, which is a normal level in arteries. EC were seeded on flexible silicon membranes coated with type I collagen (Flex-Cell International Corp, McKeesport, PA) and synchronized as described above. EC were exposed to cyclic strain using a Flexercell Strain Unit (Flexcell FX-3000 system; Flex-Cell International Corp.), which consists of a vacuum manifold with recessed ports controlled by computer program. The apparatus has been extensively characterized and utilized. The cyclic strain regimen was carried out utilizing 150 mm Hg vacuum deformation at 60 cycles/min, resulting in 24% maximum strain. EC were lysed, and total RNA was isolated using TRIzol reagent (Invitrogen), according to the manufacturer's instructions. RNA concentration and relative purity were quantified by measuring the absorbance at 260 nm and the ratio of absorbance at 260 nm relative to that at 280 nm. Twenty five μg of RNA were denatured by heating and then loaded and separated on a 1% agarose gel containing 6% formaldehyde, prior to transfer to a positively charged nylon membrane (Roche Molecular Biochemicals) by capillary blotting using 10× standard saline citrate (SSC: 1.5m sodium chloride, 0.15 m sodium citrate, pH 7.0). Hybridization was performed with probes constructed from the Egr-1 expression vector and from human MT1-MMP cDNA (12Haas T.L. Davis S.J. Madri J.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 3604-3610Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (322) Google Scholar, 13Haas T.L. Stitelman D. Davis S.J. Apte S.S. Madri J.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 22679-22685Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (173) Google Scholar), labeled with the random priming Oligolabeling Kit (AmershamBiosciences) using [α-32P]dCTP (PerkinElmer Life Sciences). Blots were then washed twice in 1× SSC, 0.1% SDS for 15 min at room temperature and then once in 0.1× SSC, 0.1% SDS for 15 min at 65 °C. Bands were visualized by standard autoradiography techniques with X-Omat AR Film (Eastman Kodak Co.). Blots were stripped and reprobed with a GAPDH probe (ATCC, Manassas, VA) to normalize for RNA loading. Whole cell extracts prepared from EC were lysed in 50 mm HEPES, 150 mm NaCl, 10% glycerol, 1 mm EDTA, 100 mm NaF, 10 mm sodium pyrophosphate, 1% Triton X-100, 1.5 mm MgCl2, 1 mmNa3VO4, 10 μg/ml leupeptin, and 1 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride. The extracts were heat-denatured in Laemmli sample buffer, size-fractionated in a 10% SDS-PAGE, and transferred to a nitrocellulose membrane (AmershamBiosciences). After blocking for 1 h with Tris-buffered saline containing 0.1% Tween 20 (TTBS) and 5% nonfat dry milk, the blots were exposed to polyclonal antibodies to MT1-MMP (Chemicon International, Inc., Temecula, CA), Egr-1, or Sp1 (Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Santa Cruz, CA). After rinsing three times for 15 min in TTBS, the blot was incubated with a 1:2,000 dilution of anti-rabbit IgGs and anti-mouse IgGs for 1 h. After three additional 15-min rinses in TTBS, the resulting protein-antibody complexes were detected by ECL (Amersham Biosciences). Confluent cells a from 35-mm 6-well culture dish were washed with phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) and scraped into 600 μl of hypotonic buffer (10 mm HEPES, pH 7.9, 10 mm KCl, 0.1 mm EDTA, 1.5 mm MgCl2, 0.5 mm dithiothreitol, 0.5 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 1× Complete mixture, 0.5 mm sodium orthovanadate). The cells were allowed to swell on ice for 15 min, and 150 μl of 10% Nonidet P-40 was added. After additional incubation for 5 min on ice and centrifugation (1,200 rpm), the supernatant was discarded. The crude nuclear pellet was resuspended and incubated for 30 min in 60 μl of hypertonic solution (20 mm HEPES, pH 7.9, 420 mm NaCl, 0.1 mm EDTA, 1.5 mm MgCl2, 0.5 mm dithiothreitol, 0.5 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 1× Complete mixture, 0.5 mm sodium orthovanadate) for high salt extraction. Cellular debris was removed by centrifugation for 10 min at 4 °C (12,000 rpm), and the glycerol was added to the supernatant (final concentration, 10% (v/v)). The protein concentration of the extract was determined using the Bio-Rad reagent (Bio-Rad), and extracts were used immediately in EMSA reactions or stored at −80 °C. Consensus Sp1 and Egr-1 binding double-stranded oligonucleotides, and mutated oligonucleotides (synthesized by Oligonucleotide Synthesis Facility, Yale University) of the MT1-MMP promoter were annealed and end-labeled using [32P]ATP (PerkinElmer Life Sciences). The probe was purified using Quick SpinTM columns (Roche Molecular Biochemicals). Ten micrograms of nuclear extract were incubated in a final volume of 20 μl containing 10 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, 50 mm NaCl, 1 mm EDTA, 0.5 mmdithiothreitol, 10% glycerol, 1 μg of poly(dI-dC), 500 ng of salmon sperm DNA, and radiolabeled probe (5 × 104 cpm) with or without unlabeled oligonucleotide competitors at 25 °C. For supershift analysis, 2 μl of the Sp1 antibody (Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Inc., Santa Cruz, CA) were added to the reaction and incubated for 15 min prior to gel loading. Nuclear extracts were pretreated with 10 milliunits of calf intestinal phosphatase (CIP) (Promega, Madison, WI) for 30 min at 25 °C in EMSA buffer prior to adding the probe. Reactions were electrophoresed on a 4% non-denaturing polyacrylamide gel containing 45 mm Tris base, 45 mm boric acid, and 1 mm EDTA followed by autoradiography. EC were washed three times with cold PBS and scraped into 500 μl of lysis buffer (50 mmTris-HCl, pH 8.0, at 4 °C, 150 mm NaCl, 2 mmEDTA, 50 mm NaF, 1% Triton X-100, 1% Nonidet P-40, 1 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 1 mm sodium orthovanadate, 1 μg of leupeptin per ml). The cells were incubated at 4 °C for 30 min with rotation. After centrifugation for 15 min, the supernatant was transferred to a fresh microcentrifuge tube, and the extract was precleared with 20 μl of protein G PLUS-agarose (Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Inc., Santa Cruz, CA) for 1 h with rotation. The beads were pelleted, and the supernatant was transferred to a new tube, and 20 μl of protein G PLUS-agarose beads conjugated to Sp1-specific antibody (Santa Cruz Biotechnology) was added. Immunoprecipitation was performed overnight at 4 °C with rotation, after which the immunoprecipitated proteins were washed four times with lysis buffer. After the last wash, the beads were resuspended in 12.5 μl of 2× Laemmli sample buffer and boiled for 5 min. The samples were separated by 10% SDS-PAGE and transferred onto a nitrocellulose membrane and probed with anti-phosphoserine-specific antibody (Zymed Laboratories Inc.). Serine-phosphorylated Sp1 was detected using an enhanced chemiluminescent system as described above. Data are presented as mean ± S.E. The Student's t test was used for analyzing densitometric data for each experiment compared with the respective static control (time, 0 min). p values of less than 0.05 were considered significant. We determined whether shear stress induced changes in MT1-MMP mRNA transcription or protein expression. Shear stress decreased MT1-MMP mRNA transcription (10, 50, and 90% reduction at 1, 4, and 8 h, respectively; p < 0.05. Fig. 1 A), and this effect was associated with a diminution in MT1-MMP protein (10, 53, and 74% reduction at 1, 4, and 8 h, respectively; p< 0.05). The inhibition by shear stress was in a time-dependent fashion (Fig. 1 B). The primary response transcription factor, Egr-1, was rapidly activated by a variety of extracellular stimuli. Egr-1 binds to a sequence found in the proximal promoter of the MT1-MMP gene in EC. As shown in Fig.2 A, shear stress induced the expression of Egr-1 mRNA rapidly and transiently. The densitometric data indicated that shear stress for 1 h induced Egr-1 mRNA transcription 7.6-fold greater than that of static control. Egr-1 protein was also induced by shear stress, which peaked at 4 h after exposure to shear stress and was 5.2-fold greater than that under static conditions (Fig. 2 B). Egr-1 mRNA and protein levels have been reported to be low or undetectable in quiescent EC but are dramatically increased upon exposure to shear stress (20Khachigian L.M. Williams A.J. Collins T. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 27679-27686Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (266) Google Scholar, 21Khachigian L.M. Collins T. Circ. Res. 1997; 81: 457-461Crossref PubMed Scopus (146) Google Scholar). The ability of Sp1 to bind to nuclear elements is critical for basal expression of MT1-MMP in static EC. The Sp1-binding sites in the MT1-MMP promoter overlap with a number of consensus elements for the structurally related transcription factor, Egr-1 (13Haas T.L. Stitelman D. Davis S.J. Apte S.S. Madri J.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 22679-22685Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (173) Google Scholar, 20Khachigian L.M. Williams A.J. Collins T. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 27679-27686Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (266) Google Scholar, 22Khachigian L.M. Fries J.W.U. Benz M.W. Bonthron D.T. Collins T. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 22637-22656Google Scholar). As shown in Fig 3, Sp1 protein levels were not affected in EC exposed to shear stress. EMSA analyses, using oligonucleotides containing wild-type MT1-MMP promoter sequences (Fig.4 A), were performed to assess Egr-1 and Sp1 binding. Nuclear extracts from EC exposed to shear stress displayed a shifted complex that was more prominent compared with extracts from cells grown under no flow conditions (Fig.4 B). Bands supershifted by an anti-Sp1 antibody were also detected in shear stress-stimulated EC. These findings indicate that increased Egr-1 protein induced by shear stress cannot displace pre-bound Sp1 protein from the MT1-MMP promoter site and, therefore, cannot up-regulate MT1-MMP expression as seen in EC exposed to cyclic strain (14Yamaguchi S. Yamaguchi M. Yatsuyanagi E. Yun S.S. Nakajima N. Madri J.A. Sumpio B. Lab. Invest. 2002; 82: 949-956Crossref PubMed Scopus (61) Google Scholar). To examine Sp1 protein binding further, we used mutant oligonucleotides, containing a GG to TA mutation within the Egr-1-binding site. This mutation blocks Egr-1 but not Sp1 binding (Fig. 5 A). As shown in Fig.5 B, EMSAs with nuclear extracts exposed to shear stress demonstrate that there were 3.8-, 5.8-, and 2.4-fold differences between the DNA affinity of Sp1 exposed to 1, 4, and 8 h of shear stress, respectively, compared with nuclear extracts from static cells (p < 0.05). These findings suggested that exposure of EC to shear stress increased Sp1 binding to the MT1-MMP promoter despite an increase in Egr-1 levels and no change in total Sp1 levels. Nogalamycin, an anthracycline isolated fromStreptomyces nogalator var. (23Fok J. Waring M. Mol. Pharmacol. 1972; 8: 65-74PubMed Google Scholar), prevents Egr-1 nucleoprotein complex formation and stimulates Sp1 phosphorylation (24Rafty L.A. Khachigian L.M. Nucleic Acids Res. 2001; 29: 1027-1033Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). We assessed the gel-shift profiles of nuclear extracts from EC treated with 10 μm nogalamycin for 0, 1, 4, or 8. Our results confirm that nogalamycin stimulates Sp1 binding to the MT1-MMP promoter site (Fig. 6). We assessed Sp1 protein binding to MT1-MMP in EC exposed to cyclic strain using the mutant oligonucleotide (Fig. 5 A) and anti-Sp1 polyclonal antibody. Exposure to cyclic strain decreased the Sp1 band, 53 and 77% at 1 and 4 h, respectively, compared with that of static cells (p < 0.05) (Fig.7). This suggests that cyclic strain decreases Sp1 binding to the MT1-MMP promoter with Egr-1 up-regulation and without a change of total Sp1 levels. We next investigated potential mechanism(s) underlying the change in affinity of Sp1 to DNA elicited by shear stress and nogalamycin. Regulation of Sp1-dependent transcription could be affected by changes in Sp1 abundance, DNA binding activity, and/or transactivation activity (25Black A.R. Jensen D. Lin S.Y. Azizkhan J.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 1207-1215Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (151) Google Scholar). Interestingly, phosphorylation has been implicated in changes in Sp1 binding and transcriptional activity (26Daniel S. Zhang S. DePaoli-Roach A.A. Kim K.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 14692-14697Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (130) Google Scholar, 27Rohlff C. Ahmad S. Borellini F. Lei J. Glazer R.I. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 21137-21141Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (188) Google Scholar). Although tyrosine residues are present, the vast majority of Sp1 phosphorylation in rat EC is on serine residues (25Black A.R. Jensen D. Lin S.Y. Azizkhan J.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 1207-1215Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (151) Google Scholar,28Borja P.F. Collins N.K., Du, P. Azizkhan-clifford J. Mudryj M. EMBO J. 2001; 20: 5737-5747Crossref PubMed Scopus (109) Google Scholar, 29Ihn H. Ihn Y. Trojanowska M. J. Invest. Dermatol. 2001; 117: 301-308Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). We investigated the effects of shear stress and Sp1 phosphorylation on EC. Lysates were prepared from EC exposed to shear stress, nogalamycin, and cyclic strain and immunoprecipitated with an anti-phosphoserine antibody. Total Sp1 levels remained relatively unchanged with shear stress, but phosphorylation of Sp1 was induced by shear stress in a time-dependent fashion (Fig.8 A) similar to the treatment of EC with nogalamycin (Fig. 8 B). Our previous studies showed that increasing levels of Egr-1, induced by cyclic strain, displaced the basal transcription factor Sp1 from the promoter, resulting in a significant greater rate of MT1-MMP transcription in microvascular EC (14Yamaguchi S. Yamaguchi M. Yatsuyanagi E. Yun S.S. Nakajima N. Madri J.A. Sumpio B. Lab. Invest. 2002; 82: 949-956Crossref PubMed Scopus (61) Google Scholar). In contrast to the shear stress and nogalomycin groups, however, there was no change in the phosphorylation state of Sp1 with cyclic strain exposure (Fig. 8 C). To confirm that these bands represent the phosphorylated form of Sp1, protein extracts were exposed to calf intestinal phosphatase (CIP) for 30 min prior to Western blot analysis. As shown in Fig.9, the density of bands was partially diminished by CIP treatment. To demonstrate that phosphorylation of Sp1 regulates the affinity of Sp1 for the MT1-MMP promoter site, EMSAs were performed on Sp1 pretreated with or without CIP. We demonstrate a significant difference between the DNA affinity of Sp1 treated with CIP, compared with Sp1 after shear stress and nogalamycin exposure without CIP (Fig. 10). Moreover, this result demonstrates that dephosphorylation of Sp1 does not abolish the binding complex completely. These results suggest that phosphorylation of Sp1 enhances the basal level of Sp1 binding to MT1-MMP promoter and transcriptional regulation of MT1-MMP. Matrix metalloproteinases constitute a family of structurally related zinc endopeptidases capable of proteolysis of numerous components of the extracellular matrix (6Birkedal-Hansen H. Curr. Opin. Cell Biol. 1995; 7: 728-735Crossref PubMed Scopus (973) Google Scholar, 30Web Z. Cell. 1997; 91: 439-442Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1124) Google Scholar). The wide substrate specificity suggests that MMPs play an important role in mediating diverse fundamental cellular programs that depend on stromal remodeling such as cell migration, angiogenesis, and wound healing (5Woessner J.F. Ann. N. Y. Acad. Sci. 1994; 732: 11-21Crossref PubMed Scopus (435) Google Scholar, 6Birkedal-Hansen H. Curr. Opin. Cell Biol. 1995; 7: 728-735Crossref PubMed Scopus (973) Google Scholar, 7Mignatti P. Rifkin D.B. Curr. Top. Microbiol. Immunol. 1996; 213: 33-50Crossref PubMed Scopus (33) Google Scholar, 31Okada A. Tomasetto C. Lutz Y. Bellocq J.P. Rio M.C. Basset P. J. Cell Biol. 1997; 137: 67-77Crossref PubMed Scopus (192) Google Scholar, 32Nagase H. Cell Res. 1998; 8: 179-186Crossref PubMed Scopus (172) Google Scholar). Whereas most MMPs are secreted, MT1-MMP, also known as MMP-14, has a single transmembrane domain and an extracellular catalytic domain that has been suggested to be a key enzyme in tumor metastasis and angiogenesis. The membrane localization makes MT1-MMP suited to function in pericellular proteolysis (33Sato H. Kinoshita T. Takino T. Nakayama K. Seiki M. FEBS Lett. 1996; 393: 101-104Crossref PubMed Scopus (297) Google Scholar); MT1-MMP also activates MMP-2 (gelatinase A) and possibly other secreted MMPs (34Hofmann U.B. Westphal J.R. Zendman A.J.W. Becker J.C. Ruiter D.J. Van Muijen G.N.P. J. Pathol. 2000; 191: 245-256Crossref PubMed Scopus (145) Google Scholar, 35Hernandez-Barrantes S. Toth M. Bernardo M.M. Yurkova M. Gervasi D.C. Raz Y. Sang Q.X.A. Fridman R. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 12080-12089Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (272) Google Scholar, 36Miyamori H. Takino T. Kobayashi Y. Tokai H. Itoh Y. Seiki M. Sato H. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 28204-28211Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (202) Google Scholar). MT1-MMP is activated during migration of EC, by culture of EC within three-dimensional collagen lattices (12Haas T.L. Davis S.J. Madri J.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 3604-3610Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (322) Google Scholar), and in cancer cells (37Kinoh H. Sato H. Tsunezuka Y. Takino T. Kawashima A. Okada Y. Seiki M. J. Cell Sci. 1996; 109: 953-959PubMed Google Scholar, 38Apte S.S. Fukai N. Beier D.R. Olsen B.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 25511-25517Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (118) Google Scholar). However, despite the correlation between MT1-MMP levels and invasive phenotype, the mechanism of MT1-MMP activation is not clear. For example in EC, the effects of mechanical stresses, such as cyclic strain or shear stress, on MT1-MMP expression have not been well demonstrated. Previously, we reported that cyclic strain increased MT1-MMP expression in rat microvascular EC (14Yamaguchi S. Yamaguchi M. Yatsuyanagi E. Yun S.S. Nakajima N. Madri J.A. Sumpio B. Lab. Invest. 2002; 82: 949-956Crossref PubMed Scopus (61) Google Scholar). Interestingly, others (15Palumbo R. Gaetano C. Melillo G. Toschi E. Remuzzi A. Capogrossi M.C. Circulation. 2000; 102: 225-230Crossref PubMed Scopus (81) Google Scholar) have demonstrated that shear stress decreases MT1-MMP expression in bovine smooth muscle cells. The enzymatic activity of MT1-MMP is regulated at several levels, including transcription, but little is known about the mechanisms underlying transcriptional regulation of MT1-MMP mRNA. Previously, we assessed the transcriptional activity of the MT1-MMP promoter region in microvessel EC using full-length and truncated promoter sequences coupled to the reporter gene encoding luciferase, and the region between −300 and −220 bp was sufficient to provide enhanced transcriptional activity (13Haas T.L. Stitelman D. Davis S.J. Apte S.S. Madri J.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 22679-22685Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (173) Google Scholar). The GC-rich sequence (−288 to −275) within this region contains overlapping consensus binding sites for Sp1 and Egr-1. Sp1 and Egr-1 transcription factors compete for binding to such regions, with higher levels of transcription occurring when increasing levels of Egr-1 displace the basal transcription factor Sp1 from the promoter sequence. Thus enhanced MT1-MMP expression in EC upon cyclic strain stimulation appears to depend on binding of Egr-1 to the MT1-MMP promoter. Egr-1 mRNA and protein levels are typically low or undetectable in EC but rapidly and transiently increase when induced by any of a large number of factors (21Khachigian L.M. Collins T. Circ. Res. 1997; 81: 457-461Crossref PubMed Scopus (146) Google Scholar, 39Khachigian L.M. Lindner V. Williams A.J. Collins T. Science. 1996; 271: 1427-1431Crossref PubMed Scopus (475) Google Scholar). Inducible expression of Egr-1-dependent genes involves displacement of prebound Sp1 by Egr-1 from their overlapping binding sites. Once bound to DNA, Egr-1 stimulates the expression of several endothelial genes such as platelet-derived growth factor-A, platelet-derived growth factor-B, transforming growth factor-β, urokinase-type plasminogen activator, and tissue factor, which are typically involved in the vascular response to injury (39Khachigian L.M. Lindner V. Williams A.J. Collins T. Science. 1996; 271: 1427-1431Crossref PubMed Scopus (475) Google Scholar). Several previous reports have shown that shear stress induces Egr-1 activation (39Khachigian L.M. Lindner V. Williams A.J. Collins T. Science. 1996; 271: 1427-1431Crossref PubMed Scopus (475) Google Scholar, 40Schwachtgen J.L. Houston P. Campbell C. Sukhatme V. Braddock M. J. Clin. Invest. 1998; 101: 2540-2549Crossref PubMed Scopus (170) Google Scholar). However, Sp1 levels are unchanged in EC exposed to shear stress (20Khachigian L.M. Williams A.J. Collins T. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 27679-27686Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (266) Google Scholar). Thus, Sp1 could be displaced from the proximal promoters of each of these induced genes by Egr-1 (21Khachigian L.M. Collins T. Circ. Res. 1997; 81: 457-461Crossref PubMed Scopus (146) Google Scholar, 39Khachigian L.M. Lindner V. Williams A.J. Collins T. Science. 1996; 271: 1427-1431Crossref PubMed Scopus (475) Google Scholar). In this study, we report that the expression of Egr-1 is induced by 14 dynes/cm2 shear stress in EC (Fig. 2), but shear stress inhibits MT1-MMP expression despite Egr-1 up-regulation (Fig. 1). To elucidate possible mechanisms underlying the MT1-MMP inhibition of shear stress, we have examined the binding profile of Sp1 and Egr-1 in the MT1-MMP promoter site. We detected a faint Sp1-DNA complex in the static cells and a more prominent Sp1-DNA complex in the extract from cells exposed to shear stress (Fig. 5). These observations imply that increasing levels of Egr-1 by shear stress cannot displace Sp1 from the promoter, and shear stress may increase the binding affinity of Sp1 to DNA, resulting in a significantly lower rate of transcription of MT1-MMP. Thus, the increased affinity of Sp1 to DNA by shear stress, rather than the Sp1 to Egr-1 ratio or the absolute amount of Egr-1, can result in the change of MT1-MMP expression in EC. Sp1 is a ubiquitous, 778-amino acid transcription factor that recognizes GC-rich sequences present in many promoters including the MT1-MMP promoter (25Black A.R. Jensen D. Lin S.Y. Azizkhan J.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 1207-1215Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (151) Google Scholar, 41Azizkhan J.C. Jensen D.E. Pierce A.J. Wade M. Crit. Rev. Eukaryotic Gene Expr. 1993; 3: 229-254PubMed Google Scholar). Regulation of Sp1-dependent transcription could be affected by changes in Sp1 abundance, DNA binding activity, and/or transactivation activity. Sp1 isO-glycosylated and phosphorylated, and both of these modifications are likely to be important in its regulation. Phosphorylation of Sp1 has been implicated in changes in Sp1 binding affinity and transcriptional activation, and changes inO-glycosylation alter the stability of Sp1 in vivo (42Han I. Kudlow J.E. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1997; 17: 2550-2778Crossref PubMed Scopus (377) Google Scholar). Although not examined here, O-glycosylation is another potential mechanism for regulation of Sp1, which has been shown to play role in the association of Sp1 with other factors and in regulation of its degradation. Recent studies (29Ihn H. Ihn Y. Trojanowska M. J. Invest. Dermatol. 2001; 117: 301-308Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) have demonstrated that serum increases Sp1 phosphorylation due to serine phosphorylation. Sp1 can be phosphorylated in vitro by protein kinase CK2 (43Armstrong S.A. Barry D.A. Leggett R.W. Mueller C.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 13489-13495Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (207) Google Scholar), a DNA-dependent protein kinase (44Jackson S.P. MacDonald J.J. Lees-Miller S. Tjian R. Cell. 1990; 63: 155-165Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (512) Google Scholar), protein kinase A (27Rohlff C. Ahmad S. Borellini F. Lei J. Glazer R.I. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 21137-21141Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (188) Google Scholar), and by cell cycle-regulated, Sp1-associated kinase activity (25Black A.R. Jensen D. Lin S.Y. Azizkhan J.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 1207-1215Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (151) Google Scholar). Sp1 can be phosphorylated at multiple sites by these kinases, which are likely to be important in regulation of its activity in response to diverse signals. DNA-dependent protein kinase has been reported to increase Sp1 activity, whereas phosphorylation of the C terminus of Sp1 by casein kinase II decreases its DNA binding property (43Armstrong S.A. Barry D.A. Leggett R.W. Mueller C.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 13489-13495Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (207) Google Scholar, 44Jackson S.P. MacDonald J.J. Lees-Miller S. Tjian R. Cell. 1990; 63: 155-165Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (512) Google Scholar). In order to demonstrate that shear stress is involved in the phosphorylation of Sp1, we performed immunoprecipitations with anti-tyrosine and anti-serine antibodies, and our results suggest that the vast majority of Sp1 phosphorylation induced by shear stress is on serine in rat microvascular EC (Fig. 7). Low levels of phosphorylation were detected only when the cells were incubated under static conditions, and serine phosphorylation was greatly increased when the cells were exposed to shear stress. Furthermore, we could demonstrate that Sp1 was not phosphorylated by cyclic strain (Fig. 7 C), and the level of DNA binding was decreased by displacement with increased Egr-1. These findings suggest that dephosphorylated Sp1 has a low affinity to bind DNA and can be displaced easily with increased Egr-1. This is supported by the findings that the amount of Sp1 and DNA complex in the nuclear extracts treated with CIP was lower than that of non-treated extracts. These findings are consistent with the recent studies that show that Sp1 phosphorylation induces increased levels of DNA binding that involve alterations in the association of Sp1 with other proteins such as Egr-1 (24Rafty L.A. Khachigian L.M. Nucleic Acids Res. 2001; 29: 1027-1033Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 25Black A.R. Jensen D. Lin S.Y. Azizkhan J.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 1207-1215Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (151) Google Scholar, 28Borja P.F. Collins N.K., Du, P. Azizkhan-clifford J. Mudryj M. EMBO J. 2001; 20: 5737-5747Crossref PubMed Scopus (109) Google Scholar, 29Ihn H. Ihn Y. Trojanowska M. J. Invest. Dermatol. 2001; 117: 301-308Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 45Merchant J.L., Du, M. Todisco A. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1999; 254: 454-461Crossref PubMed Scopus (175) Google Scholar, 46Kavurma M.M. Santiago F.S. Bonfoco E. Khachigian L.M. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 4964-4971Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (71) Google Scholar). Sp1 is a ubiquitous transcription factor that is capable of inducible regulation by several diverse mechanisms. Changes in the level of Sp1 phosphorylation are important for displacement by Egr-1 in the common binding site of the MT1-MMP promoter. Shear stress induces Sp1 phosphorylation in EC and increases its DNA binding affinity. These findings suggest that increased levels of Egr-1 cannot displace prebound Sp1 and that MT1-MMP can be inhibited by shear stress in EC. The results of this study further support a role for Sp1, not only in the regulation of basal transcription of the MT1-MMP gene but also in the modulation of the expression of this gene in response to various hemodynamic stimuli.

We have characterized the newly developed thyroid hormone antagonist NH-3 in both cell culture and in vivomodel systems. NH-3 binds Xenopus laevisthyroid hormone receptors directly in vitro and induces a conformation distinct from agonist-bound receptors. Transcriptional activation of a thyroid hormone response element-containing reporter gene is strongly inhibited by NH-3 in a dose-dependent manner. In addition, NH-3 prevents X. laevis thyroid hormone receptors from binding to the p160 family of co-activators GRIP-1 and SRC-1 in a two-hybrid assay. To assess the potency of the compound in vivo, we used induced and spontaneous X. laevis tadpole metamorphosis, a thyroid hormone-dependent developmental process. NH-3 inhibits thyroid hormone-induced morphological changes in a dose-dependent manner and inhibits the up-regulation of endogenous thyroid hormone-responsive genes. Spontaneous metamorphosis is efficiently and reversibly arrested by NH-3 with at least the same effectiveness as the thyroid hormone synthesis inhibitor methimazole. Therefore, NH-3 is the first thyroid hormone antagonist to demonstrate potent inhibition of thyroid hormone action in both cell culture- and whole animal-based assays. NH-3 binds Xenopus laevisthyroid hormone receptors directly in vitro and induces a conformation distinct from agonist-bound receptors. Transcriptional activation of a thyroid hormone response element-containing reporter gene is strongly inhibited by NH-3 in a dose-dependent manner. In addition, NH-3 prevents X. laevis thyroid hormone receptors from binding to the p160 family of co-activators GRIP-1 and SRC-1 in a two-hybrid assay. To assess the potency of the compound in vivo, we used induced and spontaneous X. laevis tadpole metamorphosis, a thyroid hormone-dependent developmental process. NH-3 inhibits thyroid hormone-induced morphological changes in a dose-dependent manner and inhibits the up-regulation of endogenous thyroid hormone-responsive genes. Spontaneous metamorphosis is efficiently and reversibly arrested by NH-3 with at least the same effectiveness as the thyroid hormone synthesis inhibitor methimazole. Therefore, NH-3 is the first thyroid hormone antagonist to demonstrate potent inhibition of thyroid hormone action in both cell culture- and whole animal-based assays. Thyroid hormones are critical regulators of vertebrate development, metabolism, and homeostasis (1Tata J.R. Biochimie (Paris). 1999; 81: 359-366Crossref PubMed Scopus (66) Google Scholar, 2Silva J.E. J. Clin. Invest. 2001; 108: 35-37Crossref PubMed Scopus (73) Google Scholar, 3Yen P.M. Physiol. Rev. 2001; 81: 1097-1142Crossref PubMed Scopus (1569) Google Scholar). In humans, various pathological states and developmental abnormalities result from inadequate or excessive levels of circulating thyroid hormones. These include mental retardation, stunted growth, hearing loss, and alterations in thermogenic homeostasis and heart rate. Therefore, the development of thyroid hormone analogs that are thyroid hormone receptor (TR) 1The abbreviations used are: TR, thyroid hormone receptor; xTR, X. laevis TR; T3, 3,5,3′-triiodothyronine; T4, thyroxine; TRE, thyroid hormone response element; MMR, Marc's modified ringers. isotype-specific agonists and antagonists may be clinically useful. In addition, such compounds would be valuable basic research tools to study the biology of thyroid hormone signaling pathways. To date, the development of potent antagonists has proven problematic. The cardiac arrhythmia drug amiodarone and its primary metabolite, desethylamiodarone, have been proposed to function in part as thyroid hormone receptor antagonists (4Norman M.F. Lavin T.N. J. Clin. Invest. 1989; 83: 306-313Crossref PubMed Scopus (64) Google Scholar). However, these compounds bind to TRs with relatively low affinity and have complex effects on receptor function, showing both agonist and antagonist activity depending on the assay (5van Beeren H.C. Bakker O. Wiersinga W.M. FEBS Lett. 2000; 481: 213-216Crossref PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar). Recently, three compounds, HY-4 (6Yoshihara H.A. Apriletti J.W. Baxter J.D. Scanlan T.S. Bioorg. Med. Chem. Lett. 2001; 11: 2821-2825Crossref PubMed Scopus (33) Google Scholar), GC-14 (7Chiellini G. Nguyen N.-H. Apriletti J.W. Baxter J.D. Scanlan T.S. Bioorg. Med. Chem. 2002; 10: 333-346Crossref PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar), and DIBRT (8Baxter J.D. Goede P. Apriletti J.W. West B.L. Feng W. Mellstrom K. Fletterick R.J. Wagner R.L. Kushner P.J. Ribeiro R.C. Webb P. Scanlan T.S. Nilsson S. Endocrinology. 2002; 143: 517-524Crossref PubMed Scopus (50) Google Scholar), were reported to bind to TRs directly and inhibit 3,5,3′-triiodothyronine (T3)-induced transcription in cultured cells. However, these compounds have relatively weak binding affinity and low potency and therefore have not yet been used successfully in an animal model. We are using Xenopus laevis metamorphosis as a simple and highly reproducible screen for biologically active thyroid hormone agonists and antagonists. The Xenopus system is a valuable model for thyroid hormone action for a number of reasons (1Tata J.R. Biochimie (Paris). 1999; 81: 359-366Crossref PubMed Scopus (66) Google Scholar,10Sachs L.M. Damjanovski S. Jones P.L., Li, Q. Amano T. Ueda S. Shi Y.B. Ishizuya-Oka A. Comp. Biochem. Physiol. B Biochem. Mol. Biol. 2000; 126: 199-211Crossref PubMed Scopus (109) Google Scholar). The Xenopus thyroid hormones, thyroxine (or T4) and the most potent form, T3, are identical in structure to the mammalian thyroid hormones (see Fig. 1) (11Dodd M.H.I. Dodd J.M. Lofts B. Physiology of the Amphibia. Academic Press, New York1976: 467-599Crossref Google Scholar). The initiation and completion of metamorphosis is dependent on thyroid hormones secreted from the developing thyroid gland (11Dodd M.H.I. Dodd J.M. Lofts B. Physiology of the Amphibia. Academic Press, New York1976: 467-599Crossref Google Scholar). Peripheral target cell concentrations of T3 are regulated through the tissue-specific expression of the highly conserved type II (D2) and type III (D3) deiodinase enzymes (12Huang H. Marsh-Armstrong N. Brown D.D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1999; 96: 962-967Crossref PubMed Scopus (147) Google Scholar, 13St. Germain D.L. Schwartzman R.A. Croteau W. Kanamori A. Wang Z. Brown D.D. Galton V.A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 11282Crossref PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar). The two thyroid hormone receptor isotypes (TRα and TRβ) (14Yaoita Y. Shi Y.B. Brown D.D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1990; 87: 7090-7094Crossref PubMed Scopus (161) Google Scholar), their heterodimer partners (RXRα, β, and γ) (15Marklew S. Smith D.P. Mason C.S. Old R.W. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1994; 1218: 267-272Crossref PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar, 16Blumberg B. Mangelsdorf D.J. Dyck J.A. Bittner D.A. Evans R.M. De Robertis E.M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 2321-2325Crossref PubMed Scopus (138) Google Scholar), and the receptor-associated co-repressors and co-activators 2E. S. Neff, W. Lim, and J. D. Furlow, unpublished results. are structurally and functionally well conserved with the mammalian counterparts. The TRs recognize thyroid hormone response elements in native target genes that contain canonical direct repeats similar to AGGTCA separated by 4 base pairs (17Furlow J.D. Brown D.D. Mol. Endocrinol. 1999; 13: 2076-2089Crossref PubMed Scopus (80) Google Scholar, 18Ranjan M. Wong J. Shi Y.B. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 24699-24705Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 19Machuca I. Esslemont G. Fairclough L. Tata J.R. Mol. Endocrinol. 1995; 9: 96-107PubMed Google Scholar). Tadpoles readily take up thyroid hormones from the aqueous rearing solution and respond in a dose-dependent and highly stereotypic manner. Each tissue responds directly and independently to the hormone based on organ culture experiments, whether the response is growth of adult cells or death of larval cells (11Dodd M.H.I. Dodd J.M. Lofts B. Physiology of the Amphibia. Academic Press, New York1976: 467-599Crossref Google Scholar, 20Yoshizato K. Int. Rev. Cytol. 1989; 119: 97-149Crossref PubMed Scopus (142) Google Scholar, 21Tata J.R. Kawahara A. Baker B.S. Dev. Biol. 1991; 146: 72-80Crossref PubMed Scopus (109) Google Scholar). Thus, amphibian metamorphosis presents a unique opportunity to address important questions regarding thyroid hormone actions that are common to all vertebrates. We report here the characterization of a new thyroid hormone receptor antagonist, NH-3 (9Nguyen N.-H. Apriletti J.W. Cunha-Lima S. Webb P. Baxter J.D. Scanlan T.S. J. Med. Chem. 2002; 45: 3310-3320Crossref PubMed Scopus (96) Google Scholar), using X. laevismetamorphosis as our model system. NH-3 appears to have improved antagonistic properties over the previous compounds that may allow characterization of its activity in vivo. We present evidence that NH-3 is indeed a potent inhibitor not only of thyroid hormone action in vitro but of induced and spontaneous metamorphosis in vivo as well. The synthesis and purification of NH-3 has been described in detail previously (9Nguyen N.-H. Apriletti J.W. Cunha-Lima S. Webb P. Baxter J.D. Scanlan T.S. J. Med. Chem. 2002; 45: 3310-3320Crossref PubMed Scopus (96) Google Scholar). Lyophilized NH-3 was reconstituted in 100% dimethyl sulfoxide (Me2SO) at a concentration of 10 mm and stored in aliquots at −20 °C until use. GC-1 was synthesized as described (22Chiellini G. Apriletti J.W. Yoshihara H. Baxter J.D. Ribeiro R.C. Scanlan T.S. Chem. Biol. 1998; 5: 299-306Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (219) Google Scholar) and stored as a 10 mmstock in Me2SO. All other chemicals were purchased from Sigma unless otherwise indicated. T3 was dissolved in 4 mmNaOH at a concentration of 1 mm and stored at −80 °C. Methimazole was dissolved in sterile water at 1 m and stored at −20 °C. Human uterine cervix cancer (HeLa) cells (Cell Culture Facility, UCSF) were grown to ∼80% confluency in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's/H-21, 4.5 g/liter glucose medium containing 10% newborn calf serum, 2 mm glutamine, 50 units/ml penicillin, and 50 μg/ml streptomycin. Cells (∼1.5 × 106) were collected and resuspended in 0.5 ml of electroporation buffer (Dulbecco's phosphate-buffered saline containing 0.1% dextrose, 10 mg/ml bioprene) with 5 μg of the TH/bZIP TRE-ΔMTV luciferase reporter plasmid (17Furlow J.D. Brown D.D. Mol. Endocrinol. 1999; 13: 2076-2089Crossref PubMed Scopus (80) Google Scholar), 0.5 μg of pRL-TK constitutive Renilla luciferase reporter plasmid (Promega), and 1 μg of either the miw xTRα or themiw xTRβ expression vector per transfection. Cells were transfected by electroporation (Bio-Rad Gene Pulser; 0.32 kV, 960 microfarad, 0.4-cm cuvettes) and plated in 12-well plates in growth medium (Dulbecco's modified Eagle's/H-21 with 10% hormone-depleted newborn calf serum). After a 6-h incubation, ligand or vehicle (EtOH) were added in triplicate. After an additional 24-h incubation, cells were harvested and assayed for luciferase activity using the Promega Dual Luciferase kit (Promega) and an Analytical Luminescence Laboratory Monolight® 3010 luminometer. Data were normalized to theRenilla luciferase activity and analyzed with the Graph-Pad computer program (GraphPad Software, Inc.) using single-site competition models to generate IC50 values. For mammalian two-hybrid assays, X. laevis TRα and TRβ hinge and ligand binding domain sequences were amplified by PCR and subcloned down-stream of the yeast transcription factor gal4 DNA binding domain in the pSG5 expression vector (gift from Dr. Marty Privalsky, UC Davis). 2.5 μg of an upstream activation sequence-containing luciferase reporter, 2.5 μg of a constitutive β-galactosidase expression vector, 1 μg of either TR LBD/gal4 DBD fusion vector, and 1 μg of an expression vector for GRIP-1/VP16 fusion protein (gift from Dr. John Baxter, UCSF) or SRC-1/gal4 activation domain fusion protein (gift from Dr. Marty Privalsky) were transfected by electroporation into HeLa cells and processed as described above. [35S]methionine-labeled (AmershamBiosciences) TRα and TRβ proteins were synthesized using TnT SP6 Coupled Wheat Germ Extract in vitro transcription and translation system (Promega). 2 μl of translated35S-labeled TR was mixed with the indicated concentrations of T3, GC-1, NH-3, or vehicle and incubated for 30 min at room temperature. 2 μg of type IV elastase (Sigma) was mixed with the TR and hormone in 96-well plates (Costar 9017), bringing the total volume to 20 μl. After a 20-min room temperature incubation, SDS-PAGE sample buffer was added followed by four 1-min freeze-thaw cycles. Samples were boiled for 10 min before SDS-PAGE analysis. The SDS-PAGE gel was fixed with 25% isopropanol and 10% acetic acid and dried for 2 h. The gel was exposed to a phosphorimager screen overnight and scanned with Storm 860 (Molecular Dynamics). The bands were quantitated using ImageQuant software. X. laevistadpoles of specific developmental stages were purchased from Nasco, Inc. The animals were tightly restaged upon receipt according to the Normal Table of X. laevis (23Nieuwkoop P.D. Faber J. Normal Table of Xenopus laevis (Daudin). 2nd Ed. Garland Publishing, Inc., New York & London1994Google Scholar). For induced metamorphosis experiments, three stage-52/53 tadpoles were added per Extra-Deep dish (Fisher) for a total of six tadpoles per group in 75 ml of 0.1× MMR (10 mm NaCl, 0.2 mm KCl, 0.1 mm MgCl2, 0.2 mm CaCl2, 0.5 mm HEPES pH 7.5). T3 concentrations of 5 nm, 15 nm, and 50 nm were used in conjunction with varying concentrations of NH-3 or the same volume of vehicle only (Me2SO or 4 mm NaOH). The solutions were changed every other day for a total of 5 days. Two stage-57 tadpoles were added per Extra-Deep dish for a total of four tadpoles per group in 75 ml of 0.1× MMR. The tadpoles were bathed in 0.25–3 μm NH-3, 1 mm methimazole, or an appropriate amount of vehicle only (Me2SO). The solutions were changed every other day, and developmental stages (23Nieuwkoop P.D. Faber J. Normal Table of Xenopus laevis (Daudin). 2nd Ed. Garland Publishing, Inc., New York & London1994Google Scholar) were recorded until the controls went through metamorphosis completely. At this point, NH-3 was removed, and the remaining tadpoles were allowed to continue through metamorphosis in 0.1× MMR. Tadpole tails were cultured in vitro as described previously (21Tata J.R. Kawahara A. Baker B.S. Dev. Biol. 1991; 146: 72-80Crossref PubMed Scopus (109) Google Scholar), with some modifications. Staged tadpoles were pretreated in 1× Steinberg's solution (10 mm HEPES, 60 mm NaCl, 0.67 mm KCl, 0.34 mm Ca(NO3)2, 0.83 mmMgSO4, pH 7.4) containing gentamycin (70 μg/ml) and streptomycin (200 μg/ml) 24 h before removal of the tail tips for culture. The tadpoles were briefly anesthetized in water containing 0.01% MS222 (aminoesterbenzoic acid, Sigma), after which 6 mm of the tail was cut and placed in 1 ml of 1× Steinberg's solution with antibiotics and 5 μg/ml insulin in 12-well Falcon tissue culture dishes (Becton-Dickinson). Tail tips were left in the culture medium for 24 h before the first hormone treatment. Afterward, the culture medium was changed every 48 h. The length of each tail was measured every 24 h, and each experimental point consisted of the mean percent length change of six tails. Total RNA was extracted from tadpole tissues using TRIzol reagent (Invitrogen) according to the manufacturer's specifications. Tissues were homogenized in TRIzol with a Tekmar Tissumizer and sheared with a 21-gauge needle three times. Synthesis of cDNA was performed using pd(N)6 (AmershamBiosciences), anti-RNase (Ambion, Inc.), and Superscript II (Invitrogen) according to the manufacturer's specifications. Quantitative PCR was performed using an Applied BioSystems GeneAmp 5700 sequence detection system, SYBR green PCR core reagents, and primers designed using Primer Express (Applied Biosystems). Collagenase-3 was detected using primers 5′-GAAGAAGCCAGGACCTTGGAT-3′and 5′-CAAATTGCAGAGCTCCGTTGA-3′. Samples were normalized using oligonucleotides specific to RNA encoding the X. laevisribosomal protein subunit L8, 5′-GCTGAGCTTTCTTGCCACAGT-3′ and 5′-GGTTGCATTCCGTGATCCTTA-3′. cDNA was diluted 1:400 for rpL8 and 1:20 for collagenase-3 before quantitative PCR. Conditions for PCR were as follows: 94 °C, 10 min followed by 40 cycles of 94 °C, 20 s; 58 °C, 30 s; and 72 °C, 30 s. The thyroid hormone antagonist NH-3 is a derivative of the selective thyromimetic GC-1 and contains a nitrophenyl acetylene moiety attached to the 5′-position of the thyronine core (Fig. 1). We employed a protease protection assay to determine whether NH-3 can bind directly to Xenopus TRs. This assay has the advantage of providing an estimate of the relative binding affinity and a means to detect conformational differences when TRs are bound to various ligands. Using elastase IV, increasing amounts of protected bands at ∼35 kDa were observed with increasing NH-3 concentrations (Fig.2 A). Binding of NH-3 by both xTRs is reduced from the agonists T3 and GC-1 by at least one order of magnitude. 3J. D. Furlow, M. Hsu, W. Lim, D. J. Ermio, H. Y. Yang, G. Chiellini, and T. S. Scanlan, submitted for publication. NH-3 appears to bind TRβ and TRα with a similar affinity (Fig. 2 B), implying that this modification of GC-1 decreases isotype selectivity. Both the relative binding affinity and decreased isotype selectivity are consistent with findings using human TRs (9Nguyen N.-H. Apriletti J.W. Cunha-Lima S. Webb P. Baxter J.D. Scanlan T.S. J. Med. Chem. 2002; 45: 3310-3320Crossref PubMed Scopus (96) Google Scholar). Saturating T3, GC-1, and NH-3 concentrations used in the protease protection assay revealed a distinct protected band pattern in both xTRα and β incubated with NH-3 (Fig. 2 C). The major band in the NH-3-protected TRs corresponds to a minor band in the agonist-bound receptors. This band represents a molecule ∼1.5 kDa smaller than the major agonist-protected band. Thus, the 5′-phenylethynyl extension of NH-3 appears to induce an xTR conformation that is distinct from the agonist-bound xTRs. To determine the effects of NH-3 on T3-induced transcription, xTRα or β expression plasmids were co-transfected with a TH/bZIP TRE-luciferase reporter gene into HeLa cells. NH-3 alone does not activate xTRα or β relative to untreated controls (Fig.3 A). In competition assays, NH-3 blocks activation by 1 nm T3 in a dose-dependent manner (Fig. 3 B). NH-3 is ∼3–4-fold more potent at antagonizing 1 nm T3 activated xTRβ relative to xTRα (∼IC50 100 nm versus 380 nm, respectively). This correlates well with the competitive binding assay data for human TRα and β, which shows ∼3-fold selective binding to the β-isotype (9Nguyen N.-H. Apriletti J.W. Cunha-Lima S. Webb P. Baxter J.D. Scanlan T.S. J. Med. Chem. 2002; 45: 3310-3320Crossref PubMed Scopus (96) Google Scholar), although this selectivity was less evident with Xenopus TRs using the protease protection assays (Fig. 2 B). The molecular basis for the antagonism of T3 by NH-3 was investigated using a two-hybrid assay in HeLa cells (Fig.4 A). xTRβ ligand binding domains were fused to the yeast transcription factor gal4 DNA binding domain and co-transfected with human GRIP-1 fused to VP16 or with human SRC-1 fused to the gal4 activation domain. As shown in Fig. 4 B, 10 μm NH-3 completely abolishes T3-induced interaction with the GRIP-1 fusion proteins and SRC-1. The half-maximal IC50for competition against 20 nm T3 was 920 nmNH-3 for GRIP-1 and 870 nm for SRC-1 (Fig. 4, Cand D). xTRα showed essentially the same result, except that the inhibition curves were shifted slightly to the right as expected based on the competition curve shown in Fig. 3 B(data not shown). Because NH-3 acts as a potent antagonist in transient transfection assays, we next tested the ability of NH-3 to inhibit thyroid hormone action in an in vivo animal model. Metamorphosis in the frog X. laevis is completely dependent on T4 and T3 secreted by the thyroid gland. Importantly, T4 and T3 can precociously induce metamorphosis by addition of these compounds to the rearing water (11Dodd M.H.I. Dodd J.M. Lofts B. Physiology of the Amphibia. Academic Press, New York1976: 467-599Crossref Google Scholar). To test whether NH-3 can inhibit T3-induced metamorphosis, premetamorphic X. laevis tadpoles were treated with 5 or 15 nm T3 versus increasing concentrations of NH-3 or with NH-3 alone. As shown in Fig.5, increasing NH-3 concentrations inhibit T3-induced branchial arch (internal gill) resorption, barbel resorption, expansion of the brain, and Meckel's cartilage growth, with 2 μm NH-3 showing maximal inhibition. Of the external morphological changes, hind limb growth is the least inhibited by NH-3, which is most easily seen in ventral views (Fig.5 B). 2 and 3 μm NH-3 were less effective in inhibiting 15 nm T3-induced morphological changes, indicating that the effects of NH-3 are the result of a simple competition with T3. 3 μm NH-3 alone shows some partial agonist activity, especially in reduction of the general size of the head. All tadpoles survived five-day treatments of these concentrations T3 and NH-3, and showed typical behaviors throughout the course of the experiment. Concentrations of NH-3 greater than 5 μm are toxic to the animals. We next examined the ability of NH-3 to inhibit T3-induced tail resorption. When tail tips are cultured in vitro, T3 strongly induces shrinkage of the tail. Maximal resorption rate is induced above 30 nm in this assay. 4D. J. Ermio and J. D. Furlow, unpublished results. As shown in Fig.6, addition of 2 μm NH-3 strongly delays tail resorption induced by 50 nm T3. Some resorption is induced by 2 μm NH-3 alone, suggesting that at this concentration NH-3 may have some partial agonist activity not observed in transient transfection assays. In addition to blocking morphological changes, NH-3 also inhibits T3-induced target gene up-regulation. For example, collagenase-3 is strongly induced by T3 during metamorphosis in resorbing and remodeling tissues (24Brown D.D. Wang Z. Furlow J.D. Kanamori A. Schwartzman R.A. Remo B.F. Pinder A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1996; 93: 1924-1929Crossref PubMed Scopus (218) Google Scholar, 25Berry D.L. Rose C.S. Remo B.F. Brown D.D. Dev. Biol. 1998; 203: 24-35Crossref PubMed Scopus (108) Google Scholar, 26Berry D.L. Schwartzman R.A. Brown D.D. Dev. Biol. 1998; 203: 12-23Crossref PubMed Scopus (122) Google Scholar). NH-3 inhibits 5 nm T3-induced collagenase-3 expression in a dose-dependent manner that closely mirrors the effects of NH-3 on morphological changes (Fig.7). With NH-3 concentrations above 2 μm, partial agonism of collagenase-3 expression is observed. Animals treated with high levels of NH-3 alone (2–3 μm) show a low level of collagenase-3 induction that is less than 10% of the 5 nm T3-induced mRNA level. We next tested the ability of NH-3 to prevent spontaneous metamorphosis induced by endogenous circulating thyroid hormones. Premetamorphic, late stage-57X. laevis tadpoles were used for these experiments. These animals have started spontaneous metamorphosis with fully formed hind limbs, but their fore limbs have not yet emerged. NH-3 delays metamorphosis in a dose-dependent manner (Fig.8, A and B), with 2 μm NH-3 completely arresting the animals at stage 57. 2 μm NH-3 is at least as effective at inhibition of metamorphosis as 1 mm methimazole (a thyroid hormone synthesis inhibitor). Removal of NH-3 allows metamorphosis to proceed normally after a lag of several days; therefore, the effects of NH-3 are fully reversible and not caused by general toxicity (data not shown). NH-3 is the first thyroid hormone receptor antagonist that effectively inhibits thyroid hormone action in an in vivosystem. NH-3 was designed based on an extension hypothesis for development of nuclear receptor antagonists (7Chiellini G. Nguyen N.-H. Apriletti J.W. Baxter J.D. Scanlan T.S. Bioorg. Med. Chem. 2002; 10: 333-346Crossref PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar). The hypothesis holds that one can predict where to modify a nuclear receptor ligand in order to place molecular extensions that should disrupt the folding of the carboxy-terminal helix 12 and therefore prevent co-activator recruitment. When bound to both Xenopus (Figs. 3 and 4) or human TRs (9Nguyen N.-H. Apriletti J.W. Cunha-Lima S. Webb P. Baxter J.D. Scanlan T.S. J. Med. Chem. 2002; 45: 3310-3320Crossref PubMed Scopus (96) Google Scholar), NH-3 competitively inhibits induction of a TRE-containing reporter gene as well as p160 co-activator protein recruitment in a dose-dependent manner. On the basis of protease protection assays performed in this study, NH-3 also clearly induces a conformational change distinct from agonist-bound TRs that may reflect the predicted misfolding of helix 12 (Fig. 2 C). The difference between the major protected bands in the agonist-versus antagonist-bound TRs (1.5 kDa) corresponds well to the predicted size of helix 12. Despite the effectiveness of NH-3 in vitro, its use in both basic research and in the clinic depends on its potency as an inhibitor of thyroid hormone effects in an intact organism. As a first step, we have exploited induced and spontaneous metamorphosis of the frogX. laevis as a convenient bioassay for NH-3. Because the interaction of NH-3 with human and Xenopus TRsin vitro is remarkably similar, metamorphosis presents an ideal bioassay to screen for compounds with thyroid hormone antagonist activity. NH-3 is remarkably effective in the inhibition of spontaneous metamorphosis as well as metamorphic changes induced by exogenously added T3. Consistent with its lower TR isotype selectivity compared with GC-1, NH-3 inhibits most observed metamorphic responses, including tissue growth as seen in the brain and Meckel's cartilage and the death of larval tissues such as the internal gills and tail. Hind limb growth is less effectively inhibited by NH-3, possibly because of its slight TRβ selectivity. NH-3 does not simply inhibit T3 uptake from the rearing medium as its mode of action because it potently blocks induction of spontaneous metamorphosis by circulating endogenous thyroid hormone levels. In this case, NH-3 is a more potent inhibitor than methimazole, a compound that prevents thyroid hormone synthesis. In addition, the effects of NH-3 are completely reversible, meaning that the antagonist is non-toxic and can be added to and removed from the animal at will. In contrast to NH-3, the previously described thyroid hormone antagonists HY-4 (6Yoshihara H.A. Apriletti J.W. Baxter J.D. Scanlan T.S. Bioorg. Med. Chem. Lett. 2001; 11: 2821-2825Crossref PubMed Scopus (33) Google Scholar) and GC-14 (7Chiellini G. Nguyen N.-H. Apriletti J.W. Baxter J.D. Scanlan T.S. Bioorg. Med. Chem. 2002; 10: 333-346Crossref PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar) do not inhibit induced metamorphosis or T3-induced gene expression at concentrations below 10 μm; higher concentrations of these compounds were found to be very toxic to the animals (data not shown). Thus, the improved design of NH-3 over previous compounds results in higher TR affinity and greater potency such that NH-3 can be used at effective but sublethal concentrations in vivo. NH-3 shows weak partial agonist activity in both gene expression and morphological assays at concentrations >2 μm in vivo. Collagenase-3 is induced to ∼10% of the level induced by the full agonist T3. Experiments using human TRs showed that NH-3 induces the release of the corepressor NCoR in addition to preventing co-activator binding (9Nguyen N.-H. Apriletti J.W. Cunha-Lima S. Webb P. Baxter J.D. Scanlan T.S. J. Med. Chem. 2002; 45: 3310-3320Crossref PubMed Scopus (96) Google Scholar). The absence of partial agonist activity in transient transfection may result from the lack of proper chromatin assembly on transfected plasmids. Besides corepressor release, weak partial agonism may result from metabolism of NH-3 to a compound with weak agonist activity in the intact animal. In summary, NH-3 will be a useful tool for studying the effects of reversibly blocking TR activity in a number of different animal systems. Prior to the availability of pharmacological probes, such studies have relied on TR-knockout mice that have irreversibly deprived the animal of expression of one or both TR isotypes throughout development (27Forrest D. Vennstrom B. Thyroid. 2000; 10: 41-52Crossref PubMed Scopus (254) Google Scholar). Certainly, the utility of NH-3 in mammals will depend on various pharmacokinetic parameters such as metabolic clearance, cellular uptake, and binding to serum proteins, all of which may differ in an amphibian model. Beyond anuran metamorphosis, thyroid hormone has been implicated in a wide range of important biological processes in organisms that lack an available genetic approach. These include direct and indirect development of amphibians and fish (28Callery E.M. Elinson R.P. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2000; 97: 2615-2620Crossref PubMed Scopus (86) Google Scholar, 29Brown D.D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1997; 94: 13011-13016Crossref PubMed Scopus (308) Google Scholar, 30Safi R. Begue A. Hanni C. Stehelin D. Tata J.R. Laudet V. J. Mol. Evol. 1997; 44: 595-604Crossref PubMed Scopus (29) Google Scholar, 31Youson J.H. Manzon R.G. Peck B.J. Holmes J.A. J. Exp. Zool. 1997; 279: 145-155Crossref PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar), the control of photoperiodism in seasonally breeding birds (32Wilson F.E. Reinert B.D. J. Comp. Physiol. B. 1993; 163: 563-573Crossref PubMed Scopus (49) Google Scholar), and smoltification of salmonids (33Specker J.L. DiStefano III, J.J. Grau E.G. Nishioka R.S. Bern H.A. Endocrinology. 1984; 115: 399-406Crossref PubMed Scopus (43) Google Scholar, 34Jones I. Rogers S.A. Kille P. Sweeney G.E. Gen. Comp. Endocrinol. 2002; 125: 226-235Crossref PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar), all of which can be explored in more mechanistic detail using NH-3. Finally, our results clearly demonstrate the degree of structural and functional relatedness between the mammalian and amphibian TRs and further underscore the usefulness of the amphibian model for identifying biologically active nuclear receptor ligands. We thank Jock Hamilton for photography, Martin Privalsky for gal4 DBD and gal4 AD expression vectors, and John Baxter for the GRIP-1-VP16 expression vector. Finally, we gratefully acknowledge the comments of our colleagues on the manuscript.

Several families of plant transcription factors contain a conserved DNA binding motif known as the homeodomain. In two of these families, named Hd-Zip and glabra2, the homeodomain is associated with a leucine zipper-like dimerization motif. A group of Hd-Zip proteins, namely Hd-ZipII, contain a set of conserved cysteines within the dimerization motif and adjacent to it. Incubation of one of these proteins, Hahb-10, in the presence of thiol-reducing agents such as dithiothreitol or reduced glutathione produced a significant increase in DNA binding. Under such conditions, the protein migrated as a monomer in non-reducing SDS-polyacrylamide gels. Under oxidizing conditions, a significant proportion of the protein migrated as dimers, suggesting the formation of intermolecular disulfide bonds. A similar behavior was observed for the glabra2 protein HAHR1, which also contains two conserved cysteines within its dimerization domain. Site-directed mutagenesis of the cysteines to serines indicated that each of them has different roles in the activation of the proteins. Purified thioredoxin was able to direct the NADPH-dependent activation of Hahb-10 and HAHR1 in the presence of thioredoxin reductase. The results suggest that redox conditions may operate to regulate the activity of these groups of plant transcription factors within plant cells. In two of these families, named Hd-Zip and glabra2, the homeodomain is associated with a leucine zipper-like dimerization motif. A group of Hd-Zip proteins, namely Hd-ZipII, contain a set of conserved cysteines within the dimerization motif and adjacent to it. Under such conditions, the protein migrated as a monomer in non-reducing SDS-polyacrylamide gels. Under oxidizing conditions, a significant proportion of the protein migrated as dimers, suggesting the formation of intermolecular disulfide bonds. A similar behavior was observed for the glabra2 protein HAHR1, which also contains two conserved cysteines within its dimerization domain. Site-directed mutagenesis of the cysteines to serines indicated that each of them has different roles in the activation of the proteins. Purified thioredoxin was able to direct the NADPH-dependent activation of Hahb-10 and HAHR1 in the presence of thioredoxin reductase. The results suggest that redox conditions may operate to regulate the activity of these groups of plant transcription factors within plant cells. The homeodomain (HD) 1The abbreviations used are: HD, homeodomain; DTT, dithiothreitol; EMSA, electrophoretic mobility shift assay; GSSG, oxidized glutathione; GSH, reduced glutathione. is a 61-amino acid protein motif found in eukaryotic transcription factors generally involved in the regulation of developmental processes (1Gehring W.J. Affolter M. Bürglin T. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1994; 63: 487-526Crossref PubMed Scopus (860) Google Scholar, 2Levine M. Hoey T. Cell. 1988; 55: 537-540Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (292) Google Scholar, 3Gehring W.J. Science. 1987; 236: 1245-1252Crossref PubMed Scopus (624) Google Scholar). It folds into a characteristic three-helix structure that interacts specifically with DNA (1Gehring W.J. Affolter M. Bürglin T. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1994; 63: 487-526Crossref PubMed Scopus (860) Google Scholar, 4Qian Y.Q. Billeter M. Otting G. Müller M. Gehring W.J. Wüthrich K. Cell. 1989; 59: 573-580Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (373) Google Scholar, 5Qian Y.K. Furukubo-Tokunaga K. Müller M. Resendez-Perez D. Gehring W.J. Wüthrich K. J. Mol. Biol. 1994; 238: 333-345Crossref PubMed Scopus (73) Google Scholar, 6Tsao D.H.H. Gruschus J.M. Wang L. Nirenberg M. Ferretti J.A. J. Mol. Biol. 1995; 251: 297-307Crossref PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar). Helices II and III form a structure that resembles the helix-turn-helix motif found in many prokaryotic transcription factors. Helix III (the recognition helix) fits into the major groove of DNA, making extensive contacts with specific bases and the sugar-phosphate backbone (7Kissinger C.R. Liu B. Martin-Blanco E. Kornberg T.B. Pabo C.O. Cell. 1990; 63: 579-590Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (803) Google Scholar, 8Otting G. Qian Y.Q. Billeter M. Müller M. Affolter M. Gehring W.J. Wüthrich K. EMBO J. 1990; 9: 3085-3092Crossref PubMed Scopus (361) Google Scholar, 9Gehring W.J. Qian Y.Q. Billeter M. Furukubo-Tokunaga K. Schier A.F. Resendez-Perez D. Affolter M. Otting G. Wüthrich K. Cell. 1994; 78: 211-223Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (702) Google Scholar, 10Wolberger C. Vershon A.K. Liu B. Johnson A.D. Pabo C.O. Cell. 1991; 67: 517-528Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (430) Google Scholar). Despite the resemblance in structure between the HD and the helix-turn-helix motif, a striking difference is that HDs usually bind DNA as monomers with high affinity (11Otting G. Qian Y.Q. Müller M. Affolter M. Gehring W.J. Wüthrich K. EMBO J. 1988; 7: 4305-4309Crossref PubMed Scopus (109) Google Scholar, 12Affolter M. Percival-Smith A. Müller M. Leupin W. Gehring W.J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1990; 87: 4093-4097Crossref PubMed Scopus (152) Google Scholar). This fact has been explained by the presence of extended contacts along the recognition helix and the N-terminal arm of the HD. HDs are present in almost every eukaryotic organism that has been investigated. In plants, several families of HD proteins have been described (13Chan R.L. Gago G.M. Palena C.M. Gonzalez D.H. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1998; 1442: 1-19Crossref PubMed Scopus (179) Google Scholar). One of these families, named Hd-Zip, comprises proteins with a typical leucine zipper motif adjacent to the C-terminal end of the HD (14Ruberti I. Sessa G. Lucchetti S. Morelli G. EMBO J. 1991; 10: 1787-1791Crossref PubMed Scopus (212) Google Scholar, 15Schena M. Davis R.W. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 3894-3898Crossref PubMed Scopus (214) Google Scholar). As expected, these proteins bind DNA as dimers (16Sessa G. Morelli G. Ruberti I. EMBO J. 1993; 12: 3507-3517Crossref PubMed Scopus (220) Google Scholar). The removal of the leucine zipper or the introduction of extra amino acids between the HD and the zipper significantly reduces binding affinity, indicating that the leucine zipper is responsible for the correct positioning of the HD for efficient binding (16Sessa G. Morelli G. Ruberti I. EMBO J. 1993; 12: 3507-3517Crossref PubMed Scopus (220) Google Scholar). The analysis of binding at different protein concentrations suggests that dimer formation is a prerequisite for DNA binding (17Palena C.M. Gonzalez D.H. Chan R.L. Biochem. J. 1999; 341: 81-87Crossref PubMed Scopus (68) Google Scholar). It has been suggested that Hd-Zip proteins may be involved in regulating developmental processes associated with the response of plants to environmental conditions (13Chan R.L. Gago G.M. Palena C.M. Gonzalez D.H. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1998; 1442: 1-19Crossref PubMed Scopus (179) Google Scholar, 18Carabelli M. Sessa G. Baima S. Morelli G. Ruberti I. Plant J. 1993; 4: 469-479Crossref PubMed Scopus (144) Google Scholar, 19Schena M. Lloyd A.M. Davis R.W. Genes Dev. 1993; 7: 367-379Crossref PubMed Scopus (120) Google Scholar). A different family of plant HD proteins, named glabra2, consists of larger proteins with an N-terminal HD. These proteins also bind DNA as dimers and possess a dimerization motif that resembles a leucine zipper truncated by a loop (20Palena C.M. Chan R.L. Gonzalez D.H. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1997; 1352: 203-212Crossref PubMed Scopus (10) Google Scholar, 21Di Cristina M. Sessa G. Dolan L. Linstead P. Baima S. Ruberti I. Morelli G. Plant J. 1996; 10: 393-402Crossref PubMed Scopus (268) Google Scholar). Most members of the glabra2 family are expressed specifically in epidermal cells, and the first member to be identified (glabra2) is involved in the development of trichomes, root hairs, and the seed coat mucilage (22Lu P. Porat R. Nadeau J.A. O'Neill S.D. Plant Cell. 1996; 8: 2155-2168Crossref PubMed Scopus (277) Google Scholar, 23Masucci J.D. Rerie W.G. Foreman D.R. Zhang M. Galway M.E. Marks M.D. Schiefelbein J.W. Development. 1996; 122: 1253-1260PubMed Google Scholar, 24Hung C.-Y. Lin Y. Zhang M. Pollock S. Marks M.D. Schiefelbein J. Plant Physiol. 1998; 117: 73-84Crossref PubMed Scopus (126) Google Scholar, 25Ingram G.C. Magnard J.-L. Vergne P. Dumas C. Rogowsky P.M. Plant Mol. Biol. 1999; 40: 343-354Crossref PubMed Scopus (53) Google Scholar, 26Rerie W.G. Feldmann K.A. Marks M.D. Genes Dev. 1994; 8: 1388-1399Crossref PubMed Scopus (467) Google Scholar). The HD and dimerization motif constitute the most conserved part of the different members of each family. Sequence analysis also revealed the presence of conserved cysteine-containing motifs within variable regions (i.e. within the variable loop in glabra2 proteins and near the C terminus of the leucine zipper in Hd-ZipII proteins). Because conserved cysteines have been reported to be involved in the redox regulation of the properties of several transcription factors (27Akamatsu Y. Ohno T. Hirota K. Kagoshima H. Yodoi J. Shigesada K. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 14497-14500Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (119) Google Scholar, 28Arnér E.S.J. Holmgren A. Eur. J. Biochem. 2000; 267: 6102-6109Crossref PubMed Scopus (2026) Google Scholar, 29Hayashi T. Ueno Y. Okamoto T. J. Biol. A. 1997; 94: 3633-3638Crossref PubMed Scopus (728) Google Scholar, 31Makino Y. Yoshikawa N. Okamoto K. Hirota K. Yodoi J. Makino I. Tanaka H. J. Biol. A. 1994; 91: 1672-1676Crossref PubMed Scopus (644) Google Scholar), we have tested the effect of oxidants and reductants on DNA binding and quaternary structure of two proteins from these families. Our results indicate that redox conditions are a key factor determining the binding of these proteins to DNA and the formation of covalent oligomeric structures. We propose that a redox-dependent mechanism may operate in vivo to modulate the activity of these transcription factors in response to metabolic and/or environmental signals. Gonzalez D.H. Guelman S. Chan R.L. Protein Expression Purif. 1998; 13: 97-103Crossref PubMed Scopus (21) Google Scholar). Fragments encoding proteins with either Cys or Ser at positions 185 and 188 were obtained by PCR on native HAHR1 and oligonucleotide 5′-GGCGAATTCTTGGTGATGCTCCCTGTG-3′ in combination with either 5′-GGGCTGGCAAGCCACGTTTGGTG-3′ (for CC-HAHR1), 5′-AAGGGTACCAGTACCAAC-3′ (for SC HAHR1), or 5′-GCGGGTACCAGTACCAACAGTGGTTTC-3′ (for SS-HAHR1). For CS HAHR1, oligonucleotides 5′-GGCGAATTCTTGGTGATGCTCCCTGTG-3′ and 5′-AAGGGTACCTGTACCAAC-3′ were used with DNA from SS-HAHR1 as template. Acta. 1997; 1351: 137-149Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar), previously cloned into theXbaI site of pMAL-c2, was used as the source for expression in pGEX4T-3 using BamHI and SalI sites for excision and cloning. Fragments encoding the entire Hd-Zip domain plus the CPSCE motif (amino acids 81–208) were amplified and cloned in-frame into the BamHI and EcoRI sites of pGEX4T-3. Amplifications were performed using oligonucleotides pGEX1 (5′-GGGCTGGCAAGCCACGTTTGGTG-3′) and CC10 (5′-CCGAATTCCCGATCTGTTCACACGAC-3′ for CCCCC-Hahb-10), SC10 (5′-CCGAATTCCCGATCTGTTCACACGACGGAGACACG-3′ for CCCSC-Hahb-10), or CS10 (5′-CCGAATTCCCGATCTGTTCAGACGAC-3′ for CCCCS-Hahb-10 and CCCSS-Hahb-10) using either native or CCCSC-Hahb-10 sequences as templates. Mutants with Cys to Ser changes within the leucine zipper were constructed using complementary oligonucleotides 5′-TAAATACTCAGAGTCCACCT-3′ and 5′-AGGTGGACTCTGAGTATTTA-3′ (for SCCCC-Hahb-10) or 5′-TAATGTGTTGGAGGATCTCTTTAA-3′ and 5′-TTAAAGAGATCCTCCAACACATTA-3′ (for CSSCC-Hahb-10) together with primers pGEX1 and CC10 to amplify partially overlapping N-terminal and C-terminal Hahb-10 fragments. The resulting products were mixed in buffer containing 50 mm Tris-HCl (pH 7.2), 10 mm MgSO4, and 0.1 mm dithiothreitol (DTT), incubated at 95 °C during 5 min, and annealed by allowing the solution to cool to 24 °C in ∼1 h. After this, 0.5 mmeach dNTP and 5 units of the Klenow fragment of Escherichia coli DNA polymerase I were added, and incubation was followed for 1 h at 37 °C. A portion of this reaction was directly used to amplify the annealed fragments using primers pGEX1 and CC10. Mutants SCCSS-Hahb-10 and CSSSS-Hahb-10 were obtained in a similar way but using primer CS10 instead of CC10 and DNA from CCCSC-Hahb-10 as template. Gene. 1988; 67: 31-40Crossref PubMed Scopus (5047) Google Scholar), with modifications described by Palena et al. (35Palena C.M. Gonzalez D.H. Guelman S. Chan R.L. Protein Expression Purif. 1997; 9: 372-378Crossref PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar). Purified proteins were dialyzed overnight at 4 °C in 50 mm Tris-HCl (pH 8.0).
